text.beginner: Dry leaves crunch under your boots as you walk down the dark street.
text.intermediate: Dry leaves crunch under your boots as you walk down the dark street.
text.advanced: Dry leaves crunch under your boots as you walk down the dark street.

text.beginner: The neighborhood is quiet. All the house lights are off.
text.intermediate: The neighborhood is silent. Every house has its lights turned off.
text.advanced: A tomb-like silence gripped the suburbs; every window remained dark, sealing the inhabitants away from the world.

text.beginner: You can still smell the strong chemicals on your uniform.
text.intermediate: You can still smell the strong scent of kerosene on your uniform.
text.advanced: The pungent, overwhelming aroma of kerosene clung to your clothes like a second skin, a permanent reminder of your profession.

text.beginner: You turn a corner and stop. A girl is standing there in a white dress.
text.intermediate: You turn a corner and stop. A girl is standing in the moonlight in a white dress.
text.advanced: Rounding the corner, you freeze. There, bathed in a pale lunar glow, stood a girl whose white dress seemed to shimmer against the shadows.

text.beginner: Hello. You’re a new neighbor, right?
text.intermediate: Of course, you’re a new neighbor, aren’t you?
text.advanced: I thought so... you're the new neighbor who moved in recently, aren't you?

text.intermediate: And you must be... the fireman.
text.advanced: And that means you must be... the fireman.

text.beginner: She looks at the orange armband on your arm and the number 451 on your helmet.
text.intermediate: She looks at the orange salamander on your arm and the 451 on your helmet.
text.advanced: Her eyes trace the orange salamander insignia on your sleeve before coming to rest on the silver '451' etched into your helmet.

text.beginner: You say that in a strange way.
text.advanced: You say that with such a peculiar inflection.

text.beginner: I would know that smell anywhere. The kerosene...
text.intermediate: I'd—I'd have known it with my eyes shut. The smell of kerosene...
text.advanced: I think I'd have recognized you even with my eyes tightly shut. It’s the scent of kerosene... it never really leaves you.

text.beginner: My wife complains about it. You can never wash it off. To me, it smells like perfume.
text.intermediate: My wife always complains. You never wash it off completely. Kerosene is nothing but perfume to me.
text.advanced: My wife is forever lamenting the scent; it's impossible to scrub away entirely. To me, however, kerosene is nothing short of perfume.

text.beginner: Happy! Of all the nonsense. You stand alone in the cold night.
text.intermediate: Happy! Of all the nonsense. You stand alone in the cold night.
text.advanced: Happy! Of all the nonsense. You stand alone in the cold night.

text.beginner: No. Houses have always been fireproof.
text.intermediate: No. Houses have always been fireproof.
text.advanced: No. Houses have always been fireproof.

text.beginner: That sounds impossible. Why save dangerous books?
text.intermediate: That sounds impossible. Why save dangerous books?
text.advanced: That sounds impossible. Why save dangerous books?

text.beginner: “What do you mean? Of course I am.”
text.intermediate: “What do you mean? Of course I am.”
text.advanced: “What do you mean? Of course I am.”
